name: Airbus A319
description: ARFF Note: Primarily aluminum construction. Overwing exits are plug-type; ensure slides are disarmed before exterior handle pull.

name: Airbus A320
description: ARFF Note: Fuel tanks in wings and center fuselage. High-pressure oxygen bottles located in forward cargo hold.

name: Airbus A321
description: ARFF Note: Stretched fuselage means increased fuel load in center tanks compared to A320. Main gear is dual-tandem on some versions.

name: Airbus A380
batteries: Multiple Li-ion locations in E/E Bays
description: ARFF Note: Double-deck evacuation risk. GLARE skin is highly fire-resistant but difficult to penetrate. Massive fuel volume hazard.

name: Airseeker R.1 (RC-135W)
description: A signals intelligence aircraft providing near-real-time on-scene intelligence collection and analysis.

name: BAe Hawk
description: Advanced jet trainer; ejector seats (Martin-Baker Mk.10) present a significant hazard to ground rescue crews.

name: Beechcraft Super King Air
description: ARFF Note: Twin-turboprop. Beware of spinning propellers during approach. Battery master located in cockpit overhead.

name: V-22 Osprey
description: Tiltrotor aircraft. Tactical note: High downwash during VTOL. Engine nacelles contain high-temperature components.

name: Boeing 747-8F
description: ARFF Note: Dedicated freighter. Main deck has no windows for entry. Nose-loading door may be jammed in nose-gear collapse.

name: Boeing 767-300
description: ARFF Note: Twin-aisle widebody. Evacuation slides are dual-lane. Overwing exits are unhinged (removable) types.

name: AH-64D Apache
description: Attack helicopter. Hazard: Ordnance may be live. Canopy jettison system uses explosive charges.

name: Boeing E-7 Wedgetail
description: Based on 737-700. MESA radar structure on top of fuselage affects center of gravity and rescue entry points.

name: C-130J Super Hercules
description: Tactical airlifter. High-wing design allows for low cargo ramp access. Defensive flare dispensers are a pyrotechnic hazard.

name: C-17 Globemaster III
description: Strategic transport. APU is located in the right wheel well sponson. Oxygen bottles in the forward left fuselage.

name: CH-47 Chinook
description: Tandem rotor helicopter. Extensive fuel load in side sponsons. Beware of low-swinging rotor blades during emergency shut-down.

name: Airbus H135 (EC135)
description: ARFF Note: Light utility helicopter. Clamshell rear doors allow stretcher access. Fenestron tail rotor is shrouded for safety.

name: F-15 Eagle
description: Air superiority fighter. Hazards: Hydrazine (on some models/emergency power), live missiles, and high-pressure hydraulics.

name: F-16 Fighting Falcon
description: Multi-role fighter. Critical: EPU uses Hydrazine (highly toxic). Do not approach if 'H' light is visible or vapor is detected.

name: F-22 Raptor
description: Stealth fighter. RAM (Radar Absorbent Material) coating releases toxic particles when burning. Full PPE and SCBA required.

name: F-35 Lightning II
description: 5th Gen Stealth. Composite material risk (CFRP). External canopy release is located on the left-hand side under a panel.

name: Grob G 115 Tutor
description: Elementary trainer. Fully composite construction (Glass Fiber Reinforced Plastic). Fire will cause rapid structural failure.

name: F/A-18 Hornet
description: Carrier fighter. Arresting hook and catapult hardware hazard. High concentration of magnesium in landing gear components.

name: McDonnell Douglas DC-3
description: ARFF Note: Vintage tail-dragger. Risk of fuel spill from carburetors on impact. No modern composite hazards.

name: Protector RG1
description: MALE RPAS. Tactical: Control link must be severed if engine is running and unresponsive. Satellite dish is high-intensity RF.

name: Saab JAS 39 Gripen
description: Light multi-role fighter. Delta-canard configuration. High use of composites in the wing and fuselage skin.

name: Sikorsky UH-60 Black Hawk
description: Utility helicopter. Sliding cabin doors. Tail boom contains drive shaft; avoid cutting through top center of boom.

name: Eurofighter Typhoon
description: Tactical Swing-role. Hazards: Carbon fiber dust, high-pressure liquid oxygen (LOX), and wing-mounted ordnance.

name: Voyager (A330 MRTT)
description: Strategic Tanker. Tactical: Carries massive fuel load in wings and center tanks. Mission controllers operate refueling pods on wings.

name: A400M Atlas
description: Strategic-tactical airlifter. Fly-by-wire controls. Propellers are composite and counter-rotating (down-between-engines).
